So my first thought with this is how cool would it be to have Glow-in-the-Dark stained glass? In the light it would be nearly invisible, but in the dark it would self illuminate. 

The only problem I can foresee is that if it actually emits light, then it would detect it's own light and stop glowing, then be dark and start glowing again, then detect it's own light again... it creates a bit of a paradox. The solution I think is to make it so the block doesn't actually emit light, only illuminate itself in the dark. 

Can you imagine if someone made a bridge with these? You could only see it at night!
That would be so cool in custom maps

It appears there is either already an existing thread on this topic (or something very similar), it's a list of items/mobs/ideas, contains a previously rejected idea, is a bug or support issue, exists, or it is too general and is being removed by our team.  Please check out this link (https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/articles/360004442111-Creating-Great-Ideas), be sure to use search, and join existing threads in progress (we read ALL the comments). Thanks!
Por favor agreguen la combat update en minecraft bedrock edition
it actually was in bedrock edition because I have Minecraft for ps3 and Minecraft on console is automatically considered bedrock edition.

It should be reintroduced. It would be good for early game and a quick way to block damage instead of the shield (which should be nerfed) It also was a fun way to say hello to people. We could see this is brought back in the 1.21 update. Which was said to be a combative update, so adding a fun and useful technique back to Minecraft could bring some people to the new combat. It could also be useful on modern PvP, and could bring some servers to the modern day era of PvP.  There's a reason most servers didn't go to the 1.9 era, because it was slow (shields) not as fun (the cooldowns were long and one miss means you're done for) The blocking with a sword could be eased into 1.21. They could make the cooldowns less annoying, and more fun, also rid of shields being OP. The shield blocks all incoming damage. The axe's cooldown makes sense, but is almost useless and is only useful to disable the opposing player's shield. I've been dissing on 1.9 this whole time, but I have enjoyed it, but changes should be made. Playing one round on pvp legacy is as long as 5 Hypixel Bedwars game. Everyone loved blocking with a shield so no one would mind it being added back into Minecraft. In addition, blocking with sword would add new reason to play and give us something we haven't seen in mainstream Minecraft for a while. Just adding it would be enough for me. Mojang here the pleas of of 1.8 players add back blocking.It was never in Bedrock, Xbox360 PS3 and WiiU count as Legacy Console Edition.

377896486872 I think the rotten wood should be made not by crafting but placing it in water and waiting, and also can be found naturally. It should be mined with silk touch. Any damage done to it(breaking or standing) will remain. Any rotten wood placed in the nether would become brittle wood(the water evaporates), which is so fragile that even a bat or arrow(the arrow gets slowed though) can pass right through it, breaking the block instantly. Breaking it(to get it) must also be done with silk touch and can be done instantly.

Here are some of my ideas for how rotten wood should work:

Rotten wood shouldn't be crafted, but instead be structure specific like cobwebs. Rotten wood is found in mineshafts, badland mineshafts, abandoned villages, shipwrecks, ocean ruins, witch hut (ceilings), pillager outpost (ceilings), woodland mansion (secret rooms), and strongholds (except libraries). It comes in 6 variants, and looks like a cracked, desaturated version of normal wood. It can be obtained with silk touch, otherwise it drops nothing.

Rotten wood shouldn't just break, but fall and then break when it hits the ground. When a rotten wood falls, it will cause adjacent rotten wood blocks to fall as well. Rotten wood will also fall when powered by redstone. It will not fall if an entity standing on it is underwater, so no randomly collapsing shipwrecks.

Lastly, rotten wood can be crafted into buttons and pressure plates. They can only be used once, as they break instead of returning back to their normal position.

The addition of lances/spears would be awesome! I would love for there to be some standard wood/stone/gold/iron/diamond lances, as an alternative to the expensive Trident. The crafting recipe could be like a diagonal shovel, and, as spears/lances have been throughout history, cheap. It would be nice if the spear did similar damage to the sword area with the difference that the spear does linear damage and not sideways.

I propose some characteristics of the spear with its enchantments.

The spear was originally a melee weapon that attacked a single target at a time but with more range than the sword and with an animation similar to playing billiards.

enchantments:

-agility: allows you to grab the spear with one hand
-penetration: allows to do area damage linearly
-Lightness: allows to launch the spear, it can only be picked up by the one who throws it doing damage per second and not damage per hit, this enchantment is incompatible with penetration
-center: When using the lance, it provides a small attraction to the tip of the lance to align the targets forward

elaboration:
a stick, a fire stick and a mineral

When mounted and sprinting, lanced should knock mounted enemies off their mounts. They should also do massive damage, really bringing cavalry into the game!

I am posting something similar (titled mounted combat and jousting)

I was going to post my own but I suppose I'll tack my specific idea on here.
- Slightly more range than trident but sword enchantments (Smite, Sharpness) can apply
- Not quite as much damage as a sword but much more useful on horseback especially
- For the sake of balance and realism, could make unwieldy/slow on ground or even only functional on horseback
- Throw mechanic from trident would be cool Ghosts'n Goblins style

Basically I noticed swords being awkward to use on horseback, and while tridents work better there is only a damage boost in rain (or I assume for those lucky enough, underwater on skeleton horse). The Lance would be a perfect middle ground designed with horseback combat in mind.
- Might have a longer "cooldown" to encourage the once per charge attack you see in medieval jousting

It'd be interesting if the lance had speed based damage, the faster you go the harder it hits. Cavalry would be a viable option, and elytra users could have a high risk/ high reward weapon. And aerial dogfights would be much more interesting!
You know now that were getting camels added to Minecraft this would be A great weapon for the charge attack that camels can provide for exceptional charge damage.

I think the lance should work as a weapon that you don't need to click to use. The speed of the lance moving past would make the damage. This means a player can move fast on a horse and skim past the enemy without having to click the enemy at the exact time. I thought three iron in a row would do it.
YES, love to be able to have jousting terminates in game. plz add this feature

With the recent release of the mace, I think it should work similarly. The higher speed in a pure horizontal path you move the more damage it does, also it should have the ability to bust shields like axes. To make it more challenging but more rewarding in terms of damage it could deal more when you time your attack with the lance the further to the edge of range the mob or player is. Since you have to move at high speeds for damage as well it makes the timing especially difficult, which means the output should be devastating in my mind.
This could be a good way to make sprint attacking viable. If damage from the mace increases with fall time, then lance damage could increase with sprint/glide/horseback riding time.

While I like your idea, I have a different idea for the lance!

In my vision, the lance would be a craftable item made from 1 stick, and 4 iron in a triangular pattern. It has further reach and can push enemies further away, making the bow optimal against it. While it doesnt deal as much damage as an iron sword, it has the useful role of dismounting enemies, which is great for minigames, roleplay, preventing players from escaping fights, and dismounting skeleton jockeys to save the skeleton horses.

I think this is a great idea it simplifies automatic farming, removes slavery, and adds a new mechanic into the game.
Always wanted this feature
This is what i want
Awesome. I was suggesting dispensers should be able to plant seeds on farmland.
We NEED this
I tried to make a fully automatic farm for wheat but I need dispensers/droppers to place seeds. WE NEED THIS

I've actually played around with mods that let you use dispensers to plant seeds- it makes for some really interesting engineering challenges. (As it turns out, timing the harvest properly, and sorting/feeding seeds back into dispensers, and making the thing tileable is harder than it seems, if extremely satisfying.)

Since food can already be obtained automatically, I think this system would encourage more innovation and design challenges than just trapping villagers and having them do it for you, which is more just irritating and morally dubious than fun or creative.

I disagree that the current method is a pro-slavery message but i do agree an automated way to plant crops would be useful. Maybe instead of the hoed ground automatically picking the item, we can use dispensers or some kind of item to "shoot" the seeds into the hoed ground. 

Or have the ability for a hopper to plant a seed to farmland if farmland is under the hopper or add a seeder block that created by using the new resources we have in the game.

Chickens laying eggs seems weird to me in Minecraft even though that is how it is in real life.

And finally, how would you get eggs, just pick them up, silk touch, do they still drop them as items every 5 minutes?

@TheIronSniper1 THe chickens will still lay eggs every 5 minutes. When you breed them, they won't actually lay eggs, they would just sit in their chosen block until the baby chicken spawns. And while I'm not an expert of automatic farms, I don't see how it effect them. Can you give an example? I might be missing somthing.

Breaking automatic farms doesn't seem like a huge problem to me for two reasons:

1. Automatic farms always seemed stupid and game-breaking to me, since it stops you from having to go out and get the items yourself.

2. Redstone engineers always find ways to make new farms, so it would only be a matter of time before they come up with a new design.

Overall I think these are great ideas (I was gonna suggest these myself), so I think it would be cool if these were added.

I love this idea!

I think they should still lay eggs at about the frequency they do currently, just as a block. After they have accumulated a certain amount (maybe six to twelve, maximum of 12 per block), then they sit on them, and after a few days they would all hatch. While the chicken is broody, it would attack any player or mob that comes within a block or two of the clutch, dealing 1 point of damage until the player/mob leaves the area. Eggs could still be collected up until they go broody, and making sure the number of eggs never gets above six would prevent them from going broody. If all the eggs get taken from a spot, then the chicken finds a new one. They always prefer hay bales over other blocks.

I think when Mojang eventually adds palm trees to the game, which they revealed and 'guarantee' will come to deserts, they should add a new mechanic for growing unique fruits based on the biome (temp/humidity); specifically, deserts/oasis (dry/arid and hot) should grow dates, a fruit from the date palm tree, and lukewarm/warm oceans / beaches (subtropical and medium rainfall) should grow coconuts, a fruit from the coconut palm tree, and finally tropical forests and jungles (wet/humid and hot) should grow either acai or pejibaye, fruits from the acai palm tree and peach palm tree respectively. I suppose an alternative for the tropical forests / jungles could be the palm trees growing bananas, but this wouldn't reflect the real world as much as these other types of fruits. Granted, these are all different fruits and tree types, despite all being classified as palm trees, though some liberalism in this regard wouldn't be un-Minecrafty and as stated would be a very unique and interesting mechanic for introducing these new types of fruit to the game from a single tree / sapling type. It would also require players to set up farms / bases in different biomes since they wouldn't be able to grow any of these fruits in plains, taiga, and other moderate or cold climates.
